Award.AwardTitle: Study of Quantum Hall Liquids Using Single Electron Transistors and Emerging Two-Dimensional Electron Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract:

At high magnetic fields, electrons that are confined to move in two directions form new states of matter known as fractional quantum Hall liquids. In such matter, new particles emerge with very unusual properties. For example, in most conductors electrical current is normally carried by electrons with a well-known charge of e. By contrast, in fractional quantum Hall liquids, current is carried by unusual particles with fractional charge of e/3, e/5, and so on. Since electrons are known to be indivisible, the emergence of such fractionally charged particles has been one most fascinating manifestations of many electron quantum phenomena. This project will study these fascinating new particles using devices called single electron transistors. The single electron transistor can be turned on and off by a single electron, and is the most sensitive charge sensor in existence. This powerful transistor will also be used to study magnetic properties of stacked layers of these unusual liquids. In addition to conventional semiconductor structures, the work will expanded to emerging two-dimensional electron systems based on higher bandgap semiconductors. On the educational side, the project will provide excellent training for graduate and undergraduate students. The outreach activities, such as physics demonstrations and public lectures, which typically focus on semiconductors, will benefit participating local high school students.

Technical Abstract:

This project will address some of the long-standing fundamental problems in two-dimensional electron systems. Excitations of fractional quantum Hall liquids are predicted to carry fractional charge and obey unusual fractional statistics different from those of fermions or bosons. Fractionalization and statistics of quasiparticles will be studied using single electron transistors (SETs) in an Aharonov-Bohm type interference structure. SETs will also be used to study bulk transport properties in quantum Hall liquids. In particular longitudinal conductivity measurements will be performed in the deep insulating regime where conventional transport measurements are not doable. Persistent eddy currents will be investigated in stacked layers of quantum Hall liquids to test an interesting prediction that such stacked layers can be perfectly diamagnetic at zero temperature. In addition to GaAs/AlGaAs heterostructures, quantum transport properties of emerging two-dimensional electron systems based on higher bandgap semiconductors will be investigated in both gated Hall bar and quantum point contact structures. On the educational side, the project will provide excellent training for graduate and undergraduate students. The outreach activities, such as physics demonstrations and public lectures, which typically focus on semiconductors, will benefit participating local high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this research program has been to study the fundamental excitations of quantum states of matter. We have mainly focused on three material systems, GaAs/AlGaAs heterostructures, GaN/AlGaN heterostructures, and samarium hexaboride (SmB6). These three material systems form interesting two-dimensional electron systems suitable for studying electron transport at different regimes. The GaAs/AlGaAs heterostructures allow us to realize low-carrier density and ultrahigh mobility two-dimensional electron systems. When placed in a perpendicular magnetic field such two-dimensional electrons exhibit a rich variety of remarkable many-body electron states, known as quantum Hall liquids, at low temperatures. The GaN/AlGaN heterostructures allowed us to study two-dimensional electron transport at the high-carrier density limit. We have studied both spin-orbit coupling and multi-channel conduction in this material system. During the last three years of this project, we focused our research on the heavy-fermion Kondo insulator SmB6. Our transport experiments provided direct evidence that this material is potentially a new type of correlated topological insulator with a truly insulating bulk and a metallic surface. Unlike other topological insulators, the insulating gap in this mixed-valent material results from the hybridization between conduction electrons and the strongly interacting f-electrons. Despite its small gap, SmB6 exhibits no bulk conduction at cryogenic temperatures, making this material ideal to study the emergent properties of 2D electron systems formed on topological insulators.

 

Following our initial experiments there has been plethora of research activity focusing on the surface states of SmB6. The current research challenges the 40 years of understanding of this illusive material, with many unique properties. We first tried to extract basic properties, such as carrier density and charge mobility of these surface states via Hall measurements, which we turned out to be rather complicated because current can flow on all surfaces of a topological insulator, each of which can have different transport characteristics. We later used Corbino structures, which allowed us measure conductivity in both parallel and perpendicular magnetic fields for different crystal surfaces. From the comparison of the conduction on both polar (100) and non-polar (110) surfaces we found that the conduction must have a non-polarity-driven origin. We have extended magneto-transport measurements up to 90 Tesla using pulsed field techniques at the National High Magnetic Field facility at Los Alamos. These experiments allowed us to quantify the closure of the gap as a function of field, which is important to distinguish between different mechanisms for the formation of hybridization gap.

 

We have also discovered a very unusual, but rather, universal property of a true topological insulator, that disorder generated by cracks in a topological insulator can lead to significant enhancement in conduction. This counter intuitive property is studied on scratched surfaces of SmB6 and has practical implications for all topological insulators.

 

The broader impacts of our research extend to three major subfields (correlated electron systems, topological insulators, and two-dimensional electron systems) of condensed matter community.
